Problem 1

Prove the remaining implications in Proposition 1.1.18:

Let (x(k))k\p{x^{\p{k}}}_k(x(k))k​ be a sequence in Rn\R^nRn.

  1. If (x(k))k\p{x^{\p{k}}}_k(x(k))k​ converges with respect to dℓ1d_{\ell^1}dℓ1​, then (x(k))k\p{x^{\p{k}}}_k(x(k))k​ converges with respect to dℓ2d_{\ell^2}dℓ2​.
  2. If (x(k))k\p{x^{\p{k}}}_k(x(k))k​ converges with respect to dℓ∞d_{\ell^\infty}dℓ∞​, then (x(k))k\p{x^{\p{k}}}_k(x(k))k​ converges with respect to dℓ1d_{\ell^1}dℓ1​.
  3. If (x(k))k\p{x^{\p{k}}}_k(x(k))k​ converges with respect to dℓ1d_{\ell^1}dℓ1​, then (x(k))k\p{x^{\p{k}}}_k(x(k))k​ converges with respect to dℓ∞d_{\ell^\infty}dℓ∞​.
Solution.

  1. Given x,y∈Rnx, y \in \R^nx,y∈Rn,

    (dℓ1(x,y))2=(∑i=1n∣xi−yi∣)2=∑i=1n∣xi−yi∣2+∑i≠j∣xi−yi∣∣xj−yj∣⏟≥0≥∑i=1n∣xi−yi∣2=(dℓ2(x,y))2.\begin{aligned} \p{d_{\ell^1}\p{x, y}}^2 = \p{\sum_{i=1}^n \abs{x_i - y_i}}^2 &= \sum_{i=1}^n \abs{x_i - y_i}^2 + \underbrace{\sum_{i \neq j} \abs{x_i - y_i} \abs{x_j - y_j}}_{\geq 0} \\ &\geq \sum_{i=1}^n \abs{x_i - y_i}^2 \\ &= \p{d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y}}^2. \end{aligned}(dℓ1​(x,y))2=(i=1∑n​∣xi​−yi​∣)2​=i=1∑n​∣xi​−yi​∣2+≥0i=j∑​∣xi​−yi​∣∣xj​−yj​∣​​≥i=1∑n​∣xi​−yi​∣2=(dℓ2​(x,y))2.​

    Thus, because metrics are non-negative,

    dℓ2(x,y)≤dℓ1(x,y).d_{\ell^2}\p{x, y} \leq d_{\ell^1}\p{x, y}.dℓ2​(x,y)≤dℓ1​(x,y).

    In particular, if lim⁡k→∞dℓ1(x(k),x(0))=0\lim_{k\to\infty} d_{\ell^1}\p{x^{\p{k}}, x^{\p{0}}} = 0limk→∞​dℓ1​(x(k),x(0))=0, then by the squeeze theorem,

    dℓ2(x(k),x(0))≤dℓ1(x(k),x(0))→k→∞0.d_{\ell^2}\p{x^{\p{k}}, x^{\p{0}}} \leq d_{\ell^1}\p{x^{\p{k}}, x^{\p{0}}} \xrightarrow{k\to\infty} 0.dℓ2​(x(k),x(0))≤dℓ1​(x(k),x(0))k→∞​0.

  2. Given x,y∈Rnx, y \in \R^nx,y∈Rn,

    dℓ1(x,y)=∑i=1n∣xi−yi∣≤∑i=1nmax⁡j=1,…,n∣xj−yj∣=ndℓ∞(x,y).\begin{aligned} d_{\ell^1}\p{x, y} = \sum_{i=1}^n \abs{x_i - y_i} \leq \sum_{i=1}^n \max_{j=1,\ldots,n} \abs{x_j - y_j} &= n d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y}. \end{aligned}dℓ1​(x,y)=i=1∑n​∣xi​−yi​∣≤i=1∑n​j=1,…,nmax​∣xj​−yj​∣​=ndℓ∞​(x,y).​

    The claim follows from the squeeze theorem like in part (1).

  3. Given x,y∈Rnx, y \in \R^nx,y∈Rn, for any 1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n, we have

    ∣xi−yi∣≤∑j=1n∣xj−yj∣=dℓ1(x,y).\abs{x_i - y_i} \leq \sum_{j=1}^n \abs{x_j - y_j} = d_{\ell^1}\p{x, y}.∣xi​−yi​∣≤j=1∑n​∣xj​−yj​∣=dℓ1​(x,y).

    Thus, because this inequality holds uniformly for all 1≤i≤n1 \leq i \leq n1≤i≤n,

    dℓ∞(x,y)=max⁡i=1,…,n∣xi−yi∣≤dℓ1(x,y).d_{\ell^\infty}\p{x, y} = \max_{i=1,\ldots,n} \abs{x_i - y_i} \leq d_{\ell^1}\p{x, y}.dℓ∞​(x,y)=i=1,…,nmax​∣xi​−yi​∣≤dℓ1​(x,y).

    The claim follows from the squeeze theorem like in part (1).

Problem 3

Prove Proposition 1.2.10.

Proposition (1.2.10)

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space, let EEE be a subset of XXX, and let x0x_0x0​ be a point in XXX. Then the following statements are logically equivalent.

  1. x0x_0x0​ is an adherent point of EEE.
  2. x0x_0x0​ is either an interior point or a boundary point of EEE.
  3. There exists a sequence (xn)n=1∞\p{x_n}_{n=1}^\infty(xn​)n=1∞​ in EEE which converges to x0x_0x0​ with respect to the metric ddd.
Solution.

We will show (i)   ⟺  \iff⟺ (ii), and then (i)   ⟹  \implies⟹ (iii)   ⟹  \implies⟹ (i).

(i)   ⟺  \iff⟺ (ii):

Recall that X=Int⁡(E)∪∂E∪Ext⁡(E)X = \Int\p{E} \cup \partial E \cup \Ext\p{E}X=Int(E)∪∂E∪Ext(E) and that this is a disjoint union. Thus, it suffices to show that x0∉Ext⁡(E)x_0 \notin \Ext\p{E}x0​∈/Ext(E). Notice that

(∀r>0:B(x0,r)∩E≠∅)  ⟺  ¬(∃r>0:B(x0,r)∩E=∅).\p{\forall r > 0 : B\p{x_0, r} \cap E \neq \emptyset} \iff \neg \p{\exists r > 0 : B\p{x_0, r} \cap E = \emptyset}.(∀r>0:B(x0​,r)∩E=∅)⟺¬(∃r>0:B(x0​,r)∩E=∅).

In other words,

x0 is an adherent point  ⟺  x∉Ext⁡(E).x_0\text{ is an adherent point} \iff x \notin \Ext\p{E}.x0​ is an adherent point⟺x∈/Ext(E).

(i)   ⟹  \implies⟹ (iii):

By definition,

∀r>0:B(x0,r)∩E≠∅.\forall r > 0 : B\p{x_0, r} \cap E \neq \emptyset.∀r>0:B(x0​,r)∩E=∅.

Thus, for each n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, we have B(x0,1n)∩E≠∅B\p{x_0, \frac{1}{n}} \cap E \neq \emptysetB(x0​,n1​)∩E=∅. Let xn∈B(x0,1n)∩Ex_n \in B\p{x_0, \frac{1}{n}} \cap Exn​∈B(x0​,n1​)∩E (this is where we use (countable) choice, but this detail isn't that important to us in this class.) Thus, we get a sequence (xn)n⊆E\p{x_n}_n \subseteq E(xn​)n​⊆E such that

d(xn,x0)≤1n→n→∞0,d\p{x_n, x_0} \leq \frac{1}{n} \xrightarrow{n\to\infty} 0,d(xn​,x0​)≤n1​n→∞​0,

so (xn)n\p{x_n}_n(xn​)n​ converges to x0x_0x0​ by the squeeze theorem.

(iii)   ⟹  \implies⟹ (i):

Let r>0r > 0r>0. Since (xn)n\p{x_n}_n(xn​)n​ converges to x0x_0x0​, there exists n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N such that

d(xn,x0)<r  ⟹  xn∈B(x0,r).d\p{x_n, x_0} < r \implies x_n \in B\p{x_0, r}.d(xn​,x0​)<r⟹xn​∈B(x0​,r).

Since xn∈Ex_n \in Exn​∈E by assumption, this means xn∈B(x0,r)∩Ex_n \in B\p{x_0, r} \cap Exn​∈B(x0​,r)∩E, i.e., this is a non-empty set.

Problem 5

Prove Proposition 1.3.4(b).

Proposition (1.3.4)

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space, let YYY be a subset of XXX, and let EEE be a subset of YYY.

  1. EEE is relatively open with respect to YYY if and only if E=V∩YE = V \cap YE=V∩Y for some set V⊆XV \subseteq XV⊆X which is open in XXX.
  2. EEE is relatively closed with respect to YYY if and only if E=K∩YE = K \cap YE=K∩Y for some set K⊆XK \subseteq XK⊆X which is closed in XXX.
Solution.

While Solution 1 is much easier than Solution 2, I highly recommend that you understand Solution 2 as well since it requires more understanding of the metric space definitions--it's very good practice.

Throughout this problem, I'll be using Proposition 1.2.15 (the long one) many times without mentioning it explicitly.

Solution 1 (using part (i))

"  ⟹  \implies⟹"

Assume EEE is relatively closed with respect to YYY. Then Y∖EY \setminus EY∖E is open in YYY, so by part (i), there exists V⊆XV \subseteq XV⊆X which is open in XXX such that Y∖E=V∩YY \setminus E = V \cap YY∖E=V∩Y. Notice that

E=Y∖(Y∖E)=Y∩(X∖(V∩Y))=Y∩((X∖V)∪(X∖Y))=(Y∩(X∖V))∪(Y∩(X∖Y))⏟=∅=Y∩(X∖V).\begin{aligned} E &= Y \setminus \p{Y \setminus E} \\ &= Y \cap \p{X \setminus \p{V \cap Y}} \\ &= Y \cap \p{\p{X \setminus V} \cup \p{X \setminus Y}} \\ &= \p{Y \cap \p{X \setminus V}} \cup \underbrace{\p{Y \cap \p{X \setminus Y}}}_{=\emptyset} \\ &= Y \cap \p{X \setminus V}. \end{aligned}E​=Y∖(Y∖E)=Y∩(X∖(V∩Y))=Y∩((X∖V)∪(X∖Y))=(Y∩(X∖V))∪=∅(Y∩(X∖Y))​​=Y∩(X∖V).​

Since VVV was open in XXX, it follows that K≔X∖VK \coloneqq X \setminus VK:=X∖V is closed in XXX.

"  ⟸  \impliedby⟸"

Assume that E=K∩YE = K \cap YE=K∩Y for some set K⊆XK \subseteq XK⊆X which is closed in XXX. Then by a similar computation as above,

Y∖E=Y∖(K∩Y)=Y∩(X∖K).Y \setminus E = Y \setminus \p{K \cap Y} = Y \cap \p{X \setminus K}.Y∖E=Y∖(K∩Y)=Y∩(X∖K).

Since KKK is closed in XXX, V≔X∖KV \coloneqq X \setminus KV:=X∖K is open in XXX. Thus, part (i), Y∖EY \setminus EY∖E is open in YYY, and hence EEE is closed in YYY.

Solution 2 (from the definitions)

"  ⟹  \implies⟹"

Assume that EEE is closed in YYY. We let K≔E‾K \coloneqq \cl{E}K:=E, where the closure is taken with respect to XXX. We immediately have E⊆E‾∩YE \subseteq \cl{E} \cap YE⊆E∩Y, so it remains to check the reverse inclusion.

Let x0∈E‾∩Yx_0 \in \cl{E} \cap Yx0​∈E∩Y. We will show that x0x_0x0​ is an adherent point of EEE in (Y,dY×Y)\p{Y, d_{Y \times Y}}(Y,dY×Y​). Let r>0r > 0r>0. Notice that because x0∈Yx_0 \in Yx0​∈Y,

BY(x0,r)=BX(x0,r)∩Y.B_Y\p{x_0, r} = B_X\p{x_0, r} \cap Y.BY​(x0​,r)=BX​(x0​,r)∩Y.

Thus,

BY(x0,r)∩E=BX(x0,r)∩E∩Y=BX(x0,r)∩E(E⊆Y)≠∅.(x0∈E‾)\begin{aligned} B_Y\p{x_0, r} \cap E &= B_X\p{x_0, r} \cap E \cap Y \\ &= B_X\p{x_0, r} \cap E && \p{E \subseteq Y} \\ &\neq \emptyset. && \p{x_0 \in \cl{E}} \end{aligned}BY​(x0​,r)∩E​=BX​(x0​,r)∩E∩Y=BX​(x0​,r)∩E=∅.​​(E⊆Y)(x0​∈E)​

Since rrr was arbitrary, this means x0x_0x0​ is an adherent point of EEE in YYY. But EEE is closed in YYY, so x0∈Ex_0 \in Ex0​∈E.

"  ⟸  \impliedby⟸"

Assume that E=K∩YE = K \cap YE=K∩Y, where KKK is a closed set in XXX. We will show that EEE contains all of its adherent points in YYY.

Let y0∈Yy_0 \in Yy0​∈Y be an adherent point of EEE in (Y,dY×Y)\p{Y, d_{Y \times Y}}(Y,dY×Y​). Since E=K∩YE = K \cap YE=K∩Y, we only need to show that y0∈Ky_0 \in Ky0​∈K. Moreover, KKK is closed in (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d), so it further suffices to show that y0y_0y0​ is an adherent point of KKK in (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d). Let r>0r > 0r>0 and notice that

E=K∩Y  ⟹  E⊆K,BY(y0,r)=BX(y0,r)∩Y  ⟹  BY(y0,r)⊆BX(y0,r).\begin{gathered} E = K \cap Y \implies E \subseteq K, \\ B_Y\p{y_0, r} = B_X\p{y_0, r} \cap Y \implies B_Y\p{y_0, r} \subseteq B_X\p{y_0, r}. \end{gathered}E=K∩Y⟹E⊆K,BY​(y0​,r)=BX​(y0​,r)∩Y⟹BY​(y0​,r)⊆BX​(y0​,r).​

In particular,

BX(y0,r)∩K⊇BY(y0,r)∩E,B_X\p{y_0, r} \cap K \supseteq B_Y\p{y_0, r} \cap E,BX​(y0​,r)∩K⊇BY​(y0​,r)∩E,

which is non-empty since y0y_0y0​ is an adherent point of EEE in (Y,dY×Y)\p{Y, d_{Y \times Y}}(Y,dY×Y​). Thus, y0y_0y0​ is an adherent point of KKK, which completes the proof.
